awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Antarctic Scallop as Key to Paleoenvironments and Sea Ice Conditions: Understanding the Modern to Predict the Past
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to discover whether the Antarctic scallop, Adamussium colbecki, provides a guide to sea-ice conditions in nearshore Antarctica today and in the past. Scallops may grow slower and live longer in habitats where sea ice persists for many years, limited by food, compared to habitats where sea ice melts out annually. Also, the chemicals retained in the shell during growth may provide crucial habitat information related to not only changing sea-ice conditions but also the type of food, whether it is recycled from the seafloor or produced by algae blooming when sea ice has melted. Unlocking the ecological imprint captured within the shell of the Antarctic Scallop will increase our understanding of changing sea-ice conditions in Antarctica. Further, because the Antarctic scallop had relatives living at the time when the Antarctic ice sheet first appeared, the scallop shell record may contain information on the stability of the ice sheet and the history of Antarctic shallow seas. Funding will also be integral for training a new generation of geoscientists in fossil and chemical forensics related to shallow sea habitats in Antarctica.

Scallops are worldwide in distribution, are integral for structuring marine communities have an extensive fossil record dating to the late Devonian, and are increasingly recognized as important paleoenvironmental proxies because they are generally well preserved in the sediment and rock record. The primary goal of this project is to assess the differences in growth, lifespan, and chemistry (stable isotopes, trace elements) archived in the shell of the Antarctic scallop that may be indicative of two ice states: persistent (multiannual) sea ice at Explorers Cove (EC) and annual sea ice (that melts out every year) at Bay of Sails (BOS), western McMurdo Sound, Antarctica. This project will investigate growth and lifespan proxies (physical and geochemical) and will use high-resolution records of stable oxygen isotopes to determine if a melt-water signal is archived in A. colbecki shells and whether that signal captures the differing ice behavior at two sites (EC versus BOS). Stable isotopes of carbon and nitrogen in association with trace elements will be used to examine subannual productivity spikes indicative of phytoplankton blooms, which are predicted to be more pronounced during open ocean conditions. Small growth increments in the outer calcite layer will be assessed to determine if they represent fortnightly growth, if so, they could provide a high-resolution proxy for monthly environmental processes. Unlocking the environmental archive preserved in A. colbecki shells may prove to be an important proxy for understanding changing sea-ice conditions in Antarctica's past. Funding will support a Ph.D. student and undergraduates from multiple institutions working on independent research projects. Web content focused on Antarctic marine communities will be designed for museum outreach, reaching thousands of middle-school children each year.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Antarctica is a unique and an integral ice-covered continent that is keeping our planet cool and fostering diverse polar ecosystems. However, recent reports concerning sea ice loss and increased glacial meltwater related to our burning of fossil fuels is greatly endangering our beautiful ice-cover continent and leading us toward a climate future that we, as humans, and the rest of the biota we share this world with, have never experienced. 

Our team wanted to know if the shell of the Antarctic scallop records Antarctic climate and environmental change, such as sea ice cover and glacial meltwater. And in turn, how those conditions may affect its growth and longevity in the coldest waters on Earth.  Occurring all around Antarctica from shallow to moderate sea depths, this wonderful scallop is a crucial ecosystem engineer, often living in high densities and providing a living space for multitudes of species living on or in its shell and a food resource for predators and scavengers.  

These scallops use sea water and the food they eat to make their shells, which in turn provides an environmental snapshot of their living conditions preserved in the shells.  Thus, our team of five undergraduates and one Ph.D. student under the mentorship of four professors, tackled this project—it was not easy as Antarctic scallop shells are extremely thin and fragile—but we solved the technical difficulties and discovered how to read the remarkable climate and environmental story that the Antarctic scallop shell records.

We first had to determine if the Antarctic scallop grew faster or slower under different sea ice conditions (thin, annual sea ice that melts out every austral summer compared to thick, multiannual sea ice that does not).  We found that growth was slower under thick, multiannual sea ice, and faster under annual sea, suggesting that the scallops were likely getting more food from phytoplankton blooms during austral summer when annual sea ice melts. Next, we had to figure out if these sea ice conditions affected their lifespan. Surprisingly, the answer was “no”:  the Antarctic scallop lives approximately 20 years under both annual and multiannual sea ice, a lifespan similar to ocean-dwelling sea scallops living in the North Atlantic Ocean!  But for us, the 20-year lifespan was perfect, as their shell records two decades of high-resolution environmental change. 

We discovered that in two decades of growth, the Antarctic Scallop lived in the same, extremely cold-water temperature—at the freezing point of sea water. But, over that 20 years, glacial melt water mixing with sea water had increased over the lifetime of the scallops.  Indeed, young scallops collected eight years after our project had a more dramatic glacial meltwater signal, which means the Antarctic scallops are recording land-based glaciers melting in Antarctica while they are living in the ocean! 

We also found that winter seasons are recorded as tightly bundled growth lines on the shells, while summer seasons had growth lines widely spaced, but this “varved” appearance only occurred on the young part of the scallop shell, not the older part, indicating that these bundles can not be used for ageing the shells as previously thought. But the summer growth bundles had a phytoplankton signal, especially for scallops living under annual sea ice; we can then target these bundles to chart phytoplankton productivity through time and sea ice conditions in Antarctica using the Antarctic scallop. Similarly, nitrogen chemistry in the shells was also distinct between annual and multiannual sea ice sites, directly related to the production and recycling of organic matter under differing sea ice cover.  Trace elements—like vitamins in the shells—also record differences in sea ice cover.   

Ancestors of the Antarctic scallop date back to the Oligocene Epoch, a time when Antarctica was just becoming ice covered. Using multiple proxies for environmental conditions archived in the Antarctic scallop shells—as we discovered in our research—are essential for unlocking sea ice duration, sea water temperature, seasonal phytoplankton blooms, and glacial melt water discharge to understand the marine shelf conditions during the Cenozoic history of Antarctica and how the biota living in those conditions responded to such changes.

We hope our work will instill the importance of Antarctica's frozen continent as well as an appreciation for its incredible and unique ecosystems, especially those communities that are dependent on annual and multiannual sea ice of this remarkable and beautiful continent.
